member.name: T:Peak.Can.Basic.BackwardCompatibility.TPCANMsg
member.summary: Represents a PCAN message.
member.remarks:
The members of this structure are sequentially byte aligned.
The structure is intended for reading and writing standard CAN messages on PCAN Channels initialized for standard CAN 2.0 A/B communication, this is, using the method for initialization and the methods and for data transmission.
For CAN communication using flexible data rate, the structure is to be used.

member.name: F:Peak.Can.Basic.BackwardCompatibility.TPCANMsg.DATA

before a variable of this type can be used in any API function.

member.name: T:Peak.Can.Basic.BackwardCompatibility.TPCANTimestamp
member.summary: Defines a time-stamp of a CAN message. The time-stamp contains the number of microseconds since the start of Windows.

note.para: The structure is intended only for retrieving the reception time of standard CAN messages of PCAN Channels initialized for standard CAN 2.0 A/B communication, this is, using the method for initialization and the method for data reading.

remarks.para: The members of this structure are sequentially byte aligned.
Calculation of total of microseconds : micros + 1000 * millis + 0x100000000 * 1000 * millis_overflow

member.name: F:Peak.Can.Basic.BackwardCompatibility.TPCANTimestamp.millis
member.summary: Represents the base-value of the timestamp, in milliseconds (0.. 2^32-1).

member.name: F:Peak.Can.Basic.BackwardCompatibility.TPCANTimestamp.millis_overflow
member.summary: Represents the roll-around value of .

member.name: F:Peak.Can.Basic.BackwardCompatibility.TPCANTimestamp.micros
member.summary: Represents the microseconds part of the timestamp (0..999).

member.name: T:Peak.Can.Basic.BackwardCompatibility.TPCANMsgFD
member.summary: Defines a CAN message with flexible data rate.

remarks.para: The members of this structure are sequentially byte aligned.

para.b: Longer Data field with CAN FD messages:

note.para: The structure is intended for reading and writing standard CAN messages as well as CAN messages with flexible data rate on PCAN Channels initialized for standard CAN-FD communication, this is, using the method for initialization and the methods and for data transmission.
For CAN communication using only the standard CAN 2.0 A/B, the structure is to be used.

member.name: F:Peak.Can.Basic.BackwardCompatibility.TPCANMsgFD.ID
member.summary: A 11/29-bit CAN message identifier.

member.name: F:Peak.Can.Basic.BackwardCompatibility.TPCANMsgFD.MSGTYPE
member.summary: The kind of CAN frame represented by this value.

member.name: F:Peak.Can.Basic.BackwardCompatibility.TPCANMsgFD.DLC
member.summary: The Data Length Code of the message (0..15).

member.name: F:Peak.Can.Basic.BackwardCompatibility.TPCANMsgFD.DATA
member.summary:
The data associated to the CAN message (DATA[0]..DATA[63]). This array must be explicitly created, for instance:
before a variable of this type can be used in any API function.

member.name: M:Peak.Can.Basic.BackwardCompatibility.PCANBasic.Initialize(System.UInt16,Peak.Can.Basic.BackwardCompatibility.TPCANBaudrate,Peak.Can.Basic.BackwardCompatibility.TPCANType,System.UInt32,System.UInt16)

remarks.note: A Channel that is initialized using must use and for communication. Calling and/or will result in a error.
Non plug-and-play channels are not CAN-FD capable.
For initializing plug-and-play channels like a PCAN-USB or PCAN-PCI card, use the method instead.
remarks.para: The parameters , , and are only required for the initialization of non plug-and-play channels.

As indicated by its name, the method initiates a PCAN Channel, preparing it for communicate within the CAN bus connected to it. Calls to the other methods will fail if they are used with a Channel handle, different than , that has not been initialized yet. Each initialized channel should be released when it is not needed anymore.

Initializing a PCAN Channel means:
to reserve the Channel for the calling application/process.
to allocate channel resources, like receive and transmit queues.
to register/connect the Hardware denoted by the channel handle.
to check and adapt the bus speed, if the Channel is already in use. (Only if the Channel was configured to adapt an available bit rate; see: parameter).
to set the channel in Listen-Only mode. (Only if the channel was configured to work in Listen-Only mode; see: parameter).
to configure the filter to catch all messages being transmitted in the bus.
to set-up the default values of the different parameters (see method ).
to set the Receive Status of the channel. (See: parameter).
Other than in the PCAN-Light API, the Initialization process will fail if an application tries to initialize a PCAN Channel that has been initialized already within the same process.
Take in consideration that initializing a channel causes a reset of the CAN hardware, when the bus status is other than OK. In this way errors like , , and , are removed.

A PCAN-LAN channel doesn't allow changing the bit rate using PCAN-Basic. In order to connect a PCAN-LAN Channel it is necessary to know the bit rate of the PCAN-Gateway device that is represented by that channel. If the bit rate is not known, the parameter should be used.

member.param: The handle of a PCAN Channel (see ).
The speed for the communication (BTR0BTR1 code).
Non-PnP: The type of hardware and operation mode.
Non-PnP: The I/O address for the parallel port.
Non-PnP: Interrupt number of the parallel port.

returns.para: The return value is a value. is returned on success. The typical errors in case of failure are:

list.item: : Indicates that the channel has been initialized but at a different bit rate as the given one.
: Indicates that the desired PCAN Channel is not valid.
: Indicates that the desired PCAN Channel is not available.

: Indicates that an action cannot be executed due to the state of the hardware. Possible causes are:
The desired PCAN Channel is a LAN Channel, which uses a different bit rate than the specified.

: Indicates that the hardware is working in a different or incompatible mode than requested. Possible causes are:
The desired PCAN Channel is being operated in CAN-FD mode.
: Indicates a problem with hardware registration, normally due to wrong values in the parameters 'HwType', 'IOPort' and 'Interrupt'.
: Indicates that the desired PCAN Channel cannot be connected because it is already in use (PCAN-Basic / PCAN-Light environment).
: Indicates that the desired PCAN Channel is being used with a different bit rate (PCAN-View).
: Indicates that the desired PCAN Channel is being used (PcanApi connection).
: The driver needed for connecting the desired PCAN Channel is not loaded.

example.para: The following example shows the initialization and uninitialization processes for a not Plug-And-Play channel (channel 1 of the PCAN-DNG). In case of failure, the returned code will be translated to a text (according with the operating system language) in English, German, Italian, French or Spanish, and it will be shown to the user.

member.name: M:Peak.Can.Basic.BackwardCompatibility.PCANBasic.InitializeFD(System.UInt16,System.String)

summary.para: Initializes a FD capable PCAN Channel.

remarks.note: A Channel that is initialized using must use and for communication. Calling and/or will result in a error.
For initializing a channel for CAN communication (no CAN-FD), use the method instead.
remarks.para: As indicated by its name, the method initiates a PCAN Channel, preparing it for communicate within the CAN bus connected to it. Calls to the other methods will fail if they are used with a Channel handle, different than , that has not been initialized yet. to reserve the Channel for the calling application/process.
to allocate channel resources, like receive and transmit queues.

The desired PCAN Channel is not CAN-FD capable and cannot be initialized using this method.
The desired PCAN Channel is a LAN Channel, which uses a different bit rate than the specified.

: Indicates that the hardware is working in a different or incompatible mode than requested. Possible causes are:

: The driver needed for connecting the desired PCAN Channel is not loaded.

example.para: The following example shows the initialization and uninitialization processes for a CAN-FD capable channel (channel 1 of a PCAN-USB Pro FD hardware). In case of failure, the returned code will be translated to a text (according with the operating system language) in English, German, Italian, French or Spanish, and it will be shown to the user.

member.name: M:Peak.Can.Basic.BackwardCompatibility.PCANBasic.Uninitialize(System.UInt16)
member.summary: Uninitializes one or all initialized PCAN Channels.

remarks.para:
A PCAN Channel can be released using one of this possibilities:
Single-Release: Giving the handle of a PCAN Channel initialized before with the method. If the given channel cannot be found an error is returned.
Multiple-Release: Giving the handle value . It instructs the API to uninitialize all channels being used by the calling application. This option does not generate errors if no channel was uninitialized.

Transmit queue on uninitialize: When a connection is terminated, the underlying hardware's transmit-queue will not be immediately discarded. The API will wait some time before terminating, so that the hardware has time to send (or try to send) the unsent messages. When the timer runs out (about 500 milliseconds), the rest of the messages in the queue (if any) are discarded.

member.param: The handle of a PCAN Channel (see ).

returns.para: The return value is a value. is returned on success. The typical errors in case of failure are:

list.item: : Indicates that the given PCAN Channel cannot be uninitialized because it was not found in the list of reserved channels of the calling application.
: Indicates that the given PCAN Channel is not valid.

example.para: The following example shows the initialization and uninitialization (Single-Release) processes for the channel . In case of failure, the returned code will be translated to a text (according with the operating system language) in English, German, Italian, French or Spanish, and it will be shown to the user. To see an example of Multiple-Release, see the method.

member.name: M:Peak.Can.Basic.BackwardCompatibility.PCANBasic.Reset(System.UInt16)
member.summary: Discards all messages contained in the receive and transmit queues of a PCAN Channel.

remarks.para: Calling this method ONLY clears the queues of a Channel. A reset of the CAN controller doesn't take place, unless the parameter is active.

Normally a reset of the CAN Controller is desired when a bus-off occur. In this case an application cannot use the channel to communicate anymore, until the CAN controller is reset. Consider using the parameter, which instructs the API to automatically reset the CAN controller when a bus-off state is detected.

Another way to reset errors like bus-off, bus-heavy and bus-light:
Performing an uninitialize / initialize cycle: This causes a hardware reset, but only when no more clients are connected to that channel.
Using the parameter : It instructs this method to explicitly perform a hardware reset regardless of whether other clients are connected to that channel.

member.param: The handle of a PCAN Channel (see ).

returns.para: The return value is a value. is returned on success. The typical errors in case of failure are:

list.item: : Indicates that the given PCAN channel was not found in the list of initialized channels of the calling application.
: Indicates that the given PCAN Channel is not valid.

example.para: The following example shows the use of the method on the channel . In case of failure, the returned code will be translated to a text (according with the operating system language) in English, German, Italian, French or Spanish, and it will be shown to the user. It is assumed that the channel was already initialized

remarks.para: When the hardware status is bus-off, an application cannot communicate anymore. Consider using the parameter, which instructs the API to automatically reset the CAN controller when a bus-off state is detected.

Another way to reset errors like bus-off, bus-warning and bus-passive:
Performing an uninitialize / initialize cycle: This causes a hardware reset, but only when no more clients are connected to that channel.
Using the parameter : It instructs this method to explicitly perform a hardware reset regardless of whether other clients are connected to that channel.

returns.para: The return value is a value. is returned on success. The typical errors in case of failure are:

: Indicates that the hardware represented by the PCAN Channel being used was removed or deactivated.
: Indicates that the given PCAN Channel is not valid.
: Indicates a bus error within the given PCAN Channel. The hardware is in bus-light status.
: Indicates a bus error within the given PCAN Channel. The hardware is in bus-heavy status.
: Indicates a bus error within the given PCAN Channel. The hardware is in bus-passive status.
: Indicates a bus error within the given PCAN Channel. The hardware is in bus-warning status.

member.name: M:Peak.Can.Basic.BackwardCompatibility.PCANBasic.Read(System.UInt16,Peak.Can.Basic.BackwardCompatibility.TPCANMsg@,Peak.Can.Basic.BackwardCompatibility.TPCANTimestamp@)
member.summary: Reads a CAN message and its time stamp from the receive queue of a PCAN Channel.

remarks.note: The use of and is mutually exclusive. The PCAN Channel passed to this method must be initialized using the method. Otherwise the error is returned.
If the timestamp of the message is not required, use the method instead.
remarks.para: The method returns CAN frames from the reception queue. It is important to call repeatedly until the reception queue becomes empty. In case there are no more messages to retrieve, the error is returned. The error is also returned if the reception of messages, configurable through the parameter, is disabled.
The receive queue can contain up to 32768 messages.

There are two possibilities for reading messages from the receive queue of a Channel:
Time-Triggered Reading: Consists in periodically calls to the method. Typically, an application starts a timer that checks for messages every 50 or 100 milliseconds, calling the method in a loop until the error or another error condition is reached.
Event-Triggered Reading: Consists in reacting to a notification sent by the PCAN driver to a registered application, when a message is received and placed in its reception queue. See Using Events to obtain more information about reading with events.
remarks.note: If a status message is read, the return value of the method is also the error code.
remarks.para: If a bus-off error occur, an application cannot use the channel to communicate anymore, until the CAN controller is reset. Consider using the parameter, which instructs the API to automatically reset the CAN controller when a bus-off state is detected.

Another way to reset errors like bus-off, bus-heavy and bus-light:
Performing an uninitialize / initialize cycle: This causes a hardware reset, but only when no more clients are connected to that channel.
Using the parameter : It instructs this method to explicitly perform a hardware reset regardless of whether other clients are connected to that channel.
The message type (see ) of a CAN message indicates if the message is a 11-bit, 29-bit, RTR, Error, or Status message. This value should be checked every time a message has been read successfully.
If the flag is set in the TPCANMsg.MSGTYPE field, the message is an Error Frame.
If the flag is set in the TPCANMsg.MSGTYPE field, the message is a PCAN Status Frame.

member.param: The handle of a PCAN Channel (see ).
A buffer to store the CAN message.
A buffer to store the reception time of the message.

returns.para: The return value is a value. is returned on success. The typical errors in case of failure are:

list.item: : Indicates that the given PCAN channel was not found in the list of initialized channels of the calling application.
: Indicates that one or more parameters passed to the method are invalid.
: Indicates that the PCAN Channel passed to the method was not initialized using the method.
: Indicates that the given PCAN Channel is not valid.
: Indicates a bus error within the given PCAN Channel. The hardware is in bus-light status. and are valid in this case.
: Indicates a bus error within the given PCAN Channel. The hardware is in bus-heavy status. and are valid in this case.
: Indicates a bus error within the given PCAN Channel. The hardware is in bus-off status. and are valid in this case.
: Indicates that the reception queue of the Channel is empty.
: Indicates that the message that has been read is not permitted due to the current settings and has been discarded.

example.para: The following example shows the use of method on the channel . In case of failure, the returned code will be translated to a text (according with the operating system language) in English, German, Italian, French or Spanish, and it will be shown to the user. It is assumed that the channel was already initialized and that the following code is called periodically, e.g. using a timer.

member.name: M:Peak.Can.Basic.BackwardCompatibility.PCANBasic.FilterMessages(System.UInt16,System.UInt32,System.UInt32,Peak.Can.Basic.BackwardCompatibility.TPCANMode)
member.summary: Configures the reception filter.

remarks.note: After a PCAN Channel is initialized, the status of its filter is fully opened.
remarks.para:
Based on the current state of the filter, calling this method causes the following behavior:
Status is : The filter is automatically closed and then configured with the given range of IDs passed to this function [, ].
Status is : The filter is set to the given range of IDs passed to this function [, ].
Status is : The filter is expanded with the given range of Ids [, ]. If a smaller or different range is required than a range that has been configured before, the filter has to be closed first before calling the method . To do this, use the method .

The parameter indicates which kind of ID is being used to register the new filter range. There are two possible values, Standard (11-bit identifier) or Extended (29-bit identifier). Standard frames are using the bit positions 28 to 18 of the Acceptance Mask/Code registers in the SJA1000 CAN controller. Drivers for 82C200 CAN controllers have to shift the bits down to positions 10 to 0.
Take into account that configuring the message filter causes the CAN controller to enter the reset state. This will affect other applications that communicate with the same PCAN hardware.

list.item: There is only one filter for standard and extended CAN messages. It seems that the ID from a standard message uses the most significant 11 bits (bit 18 to 28) of the 29 bits. I.e. the standard ID 400h is also received by indicating an extended ID 10000000h. For this reason, it is not recommended to mix standard and extended filters, since it can increase the risk of receiving unwanted messages.
Multiple calls of expand the reception filter.

It is not guaranteed that an application only receives CAN messages in the range of to . This is caused by the operating principle of the SJA1000's acceptance filter. See also Philips Data Sheet "SJA1000 Stand-alone CAN-controller".

member.param: The handle of a PCAN Channel (see ).
The lowest CAN ID to be received.
The highest CAN ID to be received.
The kind of filter being set.

returns.para: The return value is a value. is returned on success. The typical errors in case of failure are:

list.item: : Indicates that the given PCAN channel was not found in the list of initialized channels of the calling application.
: Indicates that the given PCAN Channel is not valid.

example.para: The following example shows the use of method on the channel to receive a custom range of IDs. In case of failure, the returned code will be translated to a text (according with the operating system language) in English, German, Italian, French or Spanish, and it will be shown to the user. It is assumed that the channel was already initialized.

: Indicates that the requested information is not available for the given PCAN Channel. Check the value of ; some values are not available for all PCAN-Channels or cannot be read.

In case of failure, the returned code will be translated to a text (according with the operating system language) in English, German, Italian, French or Spanish, and it will be shown to the user.

member.name: M:Peak.Can.Basic.BackwardCompatibility.PCANBasic.GetErrorText(Peak.Can.Basic.BackwardCompatibility.TPCANStatus,System.UInt16,System.Text.StringBuilder)
member.summary: Returns a descriptive text for a given code, in any of the supported languages.

remarks.para: The "Primary language IDs" are codes used by Windows OS from Microsoft, to identify a human language. Currently, following languages are supported:

member.param: The error code to translate.
The ID of the language to use for the output.

A buffer for the output text with a capacity of at least 256 bytes.
Even when currently only short texts are being returned, a text within this method can have a maximum of 255 characters plus termination. Using small buffers could lead to exceptions like an access violation in future versions of the API.

member.name: T:Peak.Can.Basic.BackwardCompatibility.NamespaceDoc
member.summary:
The namespace Peak.Can.Basic.BackwardCompatibility grants access to the PCAN-Basic library over an interface as defined within the header files PCANBasic.cs / PCANBasic.vb / PCANBasicCLR.h (C++ / CLI).
This namespace is intended to be used only with already existing projects, that have been written using those header files, as a way to keep old code working without the need of rewriting it. For new development projects the namespace Peak.Can.Basic should be used instead.

member.name: T:Peak.Can.Basic.ParameterValue
member.summary: Represents the allowed values for PCAN-Basic parameters configuration.

remarks.para: The values represented by this class and sub-classes are intended to be used:

list.item: for configuring filter, log, or trace parameters by using the method.
for configuring parameters that can be activated or deactivated by using the method.
for parsing and understanding values retrieved by the method.
for consulting range values, for instance, for preparing buffers to use with the method.
for creating a search string for the method.

member.summary: Represents the maximum amount of data bytes a CAN message can have in classic CAN 2.0A/B mode.

member.summary: Represents the maximum amount of data bytes a CAN message can have in CAN FD mode.

member.name: F:Peak.Can.Basic.ParameterValue.MaxBufferedMessages
member.summary: Represents the maximum amount of CAN messages that the receive queue of a Channel can hold.
member.remarks: When the receive queue is not read on time and more messages are received than the maximum supported, a queue overrun occurs. This means, the newest message will be included into the queue while the oldest one is discarded.

member.summary: Represents values applicable to parameters related to CAN data tracing.
member.remarks: These values are flags. There can be combined with each other

member.name: F:Peak.Can.Basic.ParameterValue.Trace.SingleFile
member.summary: A single file is generated until it size reaches MB.

remarks.para: A trace session is stored in a single and stays active until the file reaches the maximum configured file size, it is deactivated, or the PCAN Channel used is disconnected.
Tracing is automatically stopped when a file reaches the configured size limit. The method must be called using the parameter to start the tracing functionality again.

member.name: F:Peak.Can.Basic.ParameterValue.Trace.MultiFiles
member.summary: The traced data is spread over multiple files with a maximum size of MB each.

remarks.para: A trace session is stored in several files. A new file is created when a previous file reaches the maximum configured size. The tracing process stays active until it is deactivated, or the PCAN-Channel used is disconnected.

member.name: F:Peak.Can.Basic.ParameterValue.Trace.DateInFileName
member.summary: The name of the trace files contains the date the trace was started.

remarks.para: The name of the trace file additionally includes the start-date of the tracing process. The date is expressed using 8 digits with the form YYYYMMDD, where YYYY are four digits for the year, MM two digits for the month, and DD two digits for the day, e.g., 20130228_PCAN_USBBUS1.trc for the 28th of February 2013. If both, and are configured, the file name starts always with the date: "20130228140733_PCAN_USBBUS1_1.trc".

member.name: F:Peak.Can.Basic.ParameterValue.Trace.TimeInFileName
member.summary: The name of the trace files contains the time the trace was started.

remarks.para: The name of the trace file additionally includes the start-time of the tracing session. The time is expressed using 6 digits with the form HHMMSS, where HH are two digits for the hour in 24 hours format, MM two digits for the minutes, and SS two digits for the seconds, e.g., 140733_PCAN_USBBUS1.trc for the 14:07:33 (02:07:33 PM). If both, and are configured, the file name starts always with the date: "20130228140733_PCAN_USBBUS1_1.trc".

member.name: F:Peak.Can.Basic.ParameterValue.Trace.OverrideExisting
member.summary: If a file with the same name of the trace to create already exists, it is overwritten.

remarks.para: It causes the overwriting of an existence trace file when a new trace process is started. If this value is not configured, trying to start a tracing process will fail if the file name to generate is the same as one used by an existing file.

member.name: F:Peak.Can.Basic.ParameterValue.Trace.UseDataLength
member.summary: The trace file shows the column "Data Length" ('l') instead of the column "Data Length Code" ('L').

remarks.para: The "Data Length" represents the actual number of data bytes in a CAN or CAN FD message. Its value range is from 0 to 64. The "Data Length Code", as known as DLC, has a different interpretation in CAN and CAN FD. The first nine codes (0 to 8) represents 0 to 8 bytes for both. The last codes (9 to 15) represent for CAN a data length of 8. For CAN FD, these values indicate a data length between 12 and 64 bytes (see for detailed information).

member.name: T:Peak.Can.Basic.ParameterValue.LookUp
member.summary: Represents values applicable to parameters related to the method.

remarks.para: The field values represent the name of the parameters to use within the search string of the method.
Use the to get the criteria string with the desired parameters.

member.name: F:Peak.Can.Basic.ParameterValue.LookUp.DeviceType
member.summary: Search parameter representing a value.

remarks.para: The value can be represented as follow:

list.item: As a number, using decimal or hexadecimal notation.
As the conversion of the value to string.

member.name: F:Peak.Can.Basic.ParameterValue.LookUp.DeviceId
member.summary: Search parameter representing a device ID value.

remarks.para: The device ID is a value in range of a double word, [0 .. ]. It is represented as a number, using decimal or hexadecimal notation.

member.name: F:Peak.Can.Basic.ParameterValue.LookUp.ControllerNumber
member.summary: Search parameter representing a CAN controller value.

remarks.para: The controller number is a zero-based index value in range of a double word, [0 .. ]. It is represented as a number, using decimal or hexadecimal notation.

member.name: F:Peak.Can.Basic.ParameterValue.LookUp.IpAddress
member.summary: Search parameter representing an IP address value.

remarks.para: The IP address is string representing an Internet Protocol address in standard notation.
It is made of 4 octets of numbers separated by '.', each with a value in the range of a byte, [0 .. ].

member.name: F:Peak.Can.Basic.ParameterValue.LookUp.DeviceGuid
member.summary: Search parameter representing a global unique identifer (GUID).

remarks.para: The GUID is a persistent, distinctive, and immutable value stored in the flash memory of each device.
It is represented as a string of hexadecimal values in 8-4-4-4-12 format, RFC 4122.

member.summary: Represents a CAN message that is written periodically.

member.name: M:Peak.Can.Basic.Broadcast.#ctor(Peak.Can.Basic.PcanMessage,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new object.

remarks.para: After creating a object, it must be registered using the method. Unregistered objects can be recognized by checking their index. An unregistered object has -1 (0xFFFFFFFF) as index value.
The registration process assign an object a valid index in the broadcast list, trigger it for the first time, and starts its interval timer.
remarks.note: After a object is registered, any change made to it is applied directly, this means, changes made to the or the (the whole message or part of it), will be reflected when the next interval expires.

member.exception: The parameter value is null. An object of type is required.
member.param: Represents the CAN message to be written when the given expires.
Represents the interval used to write the periodically.

member.name: M:Peak.Can.Basic.Broadcast.ResetCounter
member.summary: Sets the counter of transmitted messages to 0.
member.remarks:
Each time the message associated to a object is sent, causes its to be incremented in 1.
A message is considered "sent", when it is successfully enqueued for transmission by calling the native method . This includes cases where writing a message ends with a bus error, excepting the error.

summary.para: makes use of the class to allows reading and writing from and to a PCAN Channel in an automatic way, using timers and events. It allows a more accurate filtering system that the native one, and the use of multiple receive queues with separate filter configuration.
If direct access to the PCAN-Basic interface is desired, use the class instead.

remarks.para: The object does have multiple receive queues. Only one of those receive queues is active by default when the object is created, and its filter is configured to receive any message. The remaining receive queues keep their filters closed.

The reading process is executed in an additional thread, making use of the event notification mechanism to fetch CAN messages. Fetched messages can be dequeued for their further processing using the method. If needed, messages stored in one or all receive queues may be discarded using the methods and respectively.

Each receive queue has its own message filter. This message filter can be configured using several filtering criteria, in form of data, by using the method. The message filtering in a receive queue can also be temporarily disabled/enabled at any time by using the method. A specific filtering criterion, or all of them, can be removed using the methods and respectively.
There are two approaches for sending messages to the connected CAN network:

list.item: Using the method, which places a CAN message in the connected Channel's transmit queue for immediate sending.

item.para: Using a message, which periodically places a configured CAN message in the connected Channel's transmit queue for immediate sending.

remarks.para: New items can be registered using the method. The processing of current registered items can be stopped and resumed again using their property, or the methods and respectively. A specific item, or all of them, can be removed using the methods and respectively.

member.summary: Initializes a PCAN-Basic object with its default values.

remarks.para: As default, the is configured to use the first connected PCAN USB interface, using classic CAN as protocol, and 500 kBit/s as bit rate.
A single receive queue is used, which is full open at connection time.
remarks.note:
A object can handle up to '' receive queues. Incoming messages are processed by all queues, so that the same message can be found in more than one queue, if its filter is configured to accept the message.
Only one receive queue is active by default when the object is created, and its filter is configured to receive any message.

In case of failure, an error messages is written to the console output using English as output language.

member.name: M:Peak.Can.Basic.Worker.ResetHardware
member.summary: Performs a reset of the CAN controller on the hardware connected by the object.

remarks.para: Performing a hardware reset will cause the CAN controller to go bus off for a while. This can momentarily disrupt CAN communication and affect other clients connected to the same hardware, generating error frames from other nodes and preventing messages from being sent/received.
Resetting the hardware does not discard messages that have already been read by the object. If it is desired to discard the received messages, the method should also be called.

member.returns: true if the object could perform a hardware reset; false otherwise.
member.exception: The underlying PCANBasic.dll library could not be found.
The execution of a PCAN-Basic related check operation ended with an unexpected result. Typically, this exception is triggered when a device driver is not installed or is not up to date.

example.para: The following example shows how to perform a hardware reset on a PCAN channel connected by a object.
In case of failure, an error messages is written to the console output using English as output language.

member.name: M:Peak.Can.Basic.Worker.AddFilter(Peak.Can.Basic.FilteringCriterion)
member.summary: Includes an additional filtering criterion to the message filter of the default receive queue (index 0).

remarks.para: The registers '' receive queues. These are 0-indexed. The first queue (index 0) is open by default when the object is created, meaning, its message filter is set to . All other queues remain closed, that is, their filters are configured as . The methods associated with a receive queue are overloaded, allowing either the direct use of the default queue (index 0) without specifying an index, or the use of a specific queue by passing an index.
To allow a message filter to apply filtering criteria, the status of it must be .
Duplicate filter criteria are not allowed. Attempting to include an item that already exists causes this method to fail.
remarks.note: Each time a filtering criterion is added using the state of the message filter of the associated receive queue is automatically set to .

Filtering criteria with equals to are validated first. If there is no match, those with equals to are validated. The criteria are validated in the same order as they were registered, the oldest registered criterion is validated first, the newest one is validated last.
If only exclusive filter criteria are used, messages that do not match any of them will be accepted and placed in the receive queue.

member.param: A value representing a filter criterion.
member.returns: A value indicating whether the filtering criterion was successfully added or not.

example.para: The following example shows how to configure the message filter of the default receive queue to avoid receiving messages with extended IDs 0x00000010, 0x00000011, and 0x00000012.
In case of failure, an error messages is written to the console output using English as output language.

member.name: M:Peak.Can.Basic.Worker.Dequeue(Peak.Can.Basic.PcanMessage@,System.UInt64@)
member.summary: Removes and returns a CAN messages and its timestamp from the default receive queue (index 0).
member.remarks:
Unlike the class, the class doesn't clear the receive queues on disconnect. A object muss explicitly be instructed to clear its receive queues when deactivating the connection, i.e. by calling the method, or by calling the / methods at any time.
This implies, that an application can keep processing messages after a connection to a PCAN Channel has been terminated.
member.param: A object representing a received CAN message.

The timestamp of the message, in microseconds.
On Windows, the contains the number of microseconds elapsed since system start.
On Linux, the contains the number of microseconds elapsed since the epoch (00:00 UTC, January 1st 1970).
member.returns: true if a message was successfully dequeued; otherwise, false.

example.para: The following example shows how to retrieve a message from the default receive queue (index 0).
In case of failure, an error messages is written to the console output using English as output language.

member.name: M:Peak.Can.Basic.Worker.AddBroadcast(Peak.Can.Basic.PcanMessage,System.Int32)
member.summary: Configures a CAN message to be written periodically.

remarks.para: The amount of that can be registered is limited by . Trying to configure more than that causes this method to fail.
The accuracy of the transmission interval when using objects depend on the amount of data being transmitted and fill state of the driver's transmit queue.

The transmit queue of the driver has a size of 1 MB, enough to allocate up to 32.768 classic CAN messages or 13.000 CAN FD messages. This queue is constantly in observation so that any new entry is processed and physically sent as fast as possible.

The object uses a performance timer to check the time expiration of registered objects. When a object time outs, the associated CAN message is placed in the device driver's transmit queue, as if the method had just been called.
Single objects can be temporarily deactivated using the method and reactivated again using the method. Using the property is possible to activate/deactivate the object processing.
remarks.note: If a object represents a CAN FD message but the PCAN Channel used was not initialized with support for CAN FD, it is automatically deactivated (paused), when this situation is detected.

member.param: Represents the CAN message to be written when the given expires.

member.name: M:Peak.Can.Basic.Worker.AddBroadcast(Peak.Can.Basic.Broadcast@)
member.summary: Configures a CAN message to be written periodically.

remarks.para: The amount of that can be registered is limited by . Trying to configure more than that causes this method to fail.
The accuracy of the transmission interval when using objects depend on the amount of data being transmitted and fill state of the driver's transmit queue.

The transmit queue of the driver has a size of 1 MB, enough to allocate up to 32.768 classic CAN messages or 13.000 CAN FD messages. This queue is constantly in observation so that any new entry is processed and physically sent as fast as possible.

The object uses a performance timer to check the time expiration of registered objects. When a object time outs, the associated CAN message is placed in the device driver's transmit queue, as if the method had just been called.
Single objects can be temporarily deactivated using the method and reactivated again using the method. Using the property is possible to activate/deactivate the object processing.
remarks.note: If a object represents a CAN FD message but the PCAN Channel used was not initialized with support for CAN FD, it is automatically deactivated (paused), when this situation is detected.

member.name: M:Peak.Can.Basic.Api.Initialize(Peak.Can.Basic.PcanChannel,Peak.Can.Basic.Bitrate)
member.summary: Initializes a PCAN Channel for classic CAN communication.

remarks.note: For initializing a CAN FD capable Channel for CAN FD communication use the method instead.

This method will fail if an application tries to initialize a PCAN Channel that has been already initialized. The PCAN Channel must be first finalized using the method, to be able to call or on it again.
remarks.para: As indicated by its name, the method initiates a PCAN Channel, preparing it for communicate within the CAN bus connected to it. Calls to other methods will fail if they are used with a Channel handle, different than , that has not been initialized yet. Each initialized channel should be released when it is not needed anymore.

Initializing a PCAN Channel means:
to reserve the Channel for the calling application/process.
to allocate Channel resources, like receive and transmit queues.
to register/connect the Hardware denoted by the Channel handle.
to check and adapt the bus speed, if the Channel is already in use - only if the Channel was configured to adapt an available bit rate (see: parameter).
to set the Channel in Listen-Only mode - only if the Channel was configured to work in Listen-Only mode (see: parameter).
to open the filter, i.e., configure the filter to capture all messages that are transmitted on the bus.
to set-up the default values of the different parameters (see method ).
to activate the receive status for the Channel. (See: parameter).
Take in consideration that initializing a Channel causes a reset of the CAN hardware, when the bus status is other than OK. In this way errors like , , and , are removed.

A PCAN-LAN Channel doesn't allow changing the bit rate using PCAN-Basic. In order to connect a PCAN-LAN Channel it is necessary to know the bit rate of the CAN controller on the PCAN-Gateway device that is represented by that Channel. To initialize the Channel without having to specify the correct bit rate, the parameter can be used.

member.param: The handle of a PCAN Channel.
The speed for the communication (BTR0/BTR1 code). Default is 500 kBit/s ().

returns.para: is returned on success. The typical errors in case of failure are:

list.item: : Indicates that the has been initialized but at a different bit rate than the specified in .
: Indicates that the contains an invalid value.
: Indicates that the is not available.

: Indicates that an action cannot be executed due to the state of the hardware. Possible causes are:
The is a Channel, which uses a different bit rate than the specified.

: Indicates that the hardware is working in a different or incompatible mode than requested. Possible causes are:
The is being operated in CAN FD mode.
: Indicates that the cannot be connected because it is already in use (PCAN-Basic / PCAN-Light environment).
: Indicates that the is being used with a different bit rate (PCAN-View).
: Indicates that the is being already used (PcanApi connection).
: Indicates that the device driver needed for connecting the is not loaded.

member.exception: The underlying PCANBasic.dll library could not be found.
The execution of a PCAN-Basic related check operation ended with an unexpected result. Typically, this exception is triggered when a device driver is not installed or is not up to date.

example.para: The following example shows the initialization and uninitialization processes using the USB interface (first PCAN-USB hardware).
In case of failure, the returned code will be translated to a text (according with the operating system language) in English, German, Italian, French or Spanish, and it will be shown to the user.

member.name: M:Peak.Can.Basic.Api.Uninitialize(Peak.Can.Basic.PcanChannel)
member.summary: Uninitializes one or all PCAN Channels initialized by the methods and .

remarks.para:
This method can be used to achieve two different goals:
To release a single Channel: Passing the handle of a PCAN Channel initialized before as parameter (see / ) terminates the connection with that Chanel. If the given channel cannot be found, an error is returned.
To release all connected Channels: Passing the Channel as parameter, terminates all connections, that have been issued and maintained by the calling application. This operation does not generate errors if no Channels were found and terminated.

note.para: When a connection is terminated, the underlying hardware's transmit queue will not be immediately discarded. The API will wait some time before terminating, so that the hardware has time to send (or try to send) the unsent messages. When this time runs out (about 500 milliseconds), the rest of the messages in the queue (if any) are discarded.

member.param: The handle of a PCAN Channel.

returns.para: is returned on success. The typical errors in case of failure are:

list.item: : Indicates that the cannot be terminated because it was not found in the list of reserved Channels of the calling application.
: Indicates that the contains an invalid value.

member.exception: The underlying PCANBasic.dll library could not be found.
The execution of a PCAN-Basic related check operation ended with an unexpected result. Typically, this exception is triggered when a device driver is not installed or is not up to date.

In case of failure, the returned code will be translated to a text (according with the operating system language) in English, German, Italian, French or Spanish, and it will be shown to the user.
The following example shows the multiple release process using the USB interface (first and second PCAN-USB hardware).

member.name: M:Peak.Can.Basic.Api.Reset(Peak.Can.Basic.PcanChannel)
member.summary: Discards all messages contained in the receive and transmit queues of a PCAN Channel.

remarks.para: Calling this method ONLY clears the queues of a Channel. A reset of the CAN controller doesn't take place, unless the parameter is active.

Normally a reset of the CAN Controller is desired when a bus-off occur. In this case an application cannot use the channel to communicate anymore, until the CAN controller is reset. Consider using the parameter, which instructs the API to automatically reset the CAN controller when a bus-off state is detected.

Another way to reset bus errors like , , and others:
Performing an uninitialize / initialize cycle: This causes a hardware reset, but only when no more clients are connected to that channel.
Using the parameter : It instructs this method to explicitly perform a hardware reset regardless of whether other clients are connected to that channel.

member.param: The handle of a PCAN Channel.

returns.para: is returned on success. The typical errors in case of failure are:

list.item: : Indicates that the cannot be used because it was not found in the list of reserved Channels of the calling application.
: Indicates that the contains an invalid value.

member.exception: The underlying PCANBasic.dll library could not be found.
The execution of a PCAN-Basic related check operation ended with an unexpected result. Typically, this exception is triggered when a device driver is not installed or is not up to date.

example.para: The following example shows the use of the method using the USB interface (first PCAN-USB hardware). This example assumes that there is communication taking place on the CAN bus.
In case of failure, the returned code will be translated to a text (according with the operating system language) in English, German, Italian, French or Spanish, and it will be shown to the user.

member.summary: Retrieves the current status of the CAN controller of the hardware represented by a PCAN Channel.

remarks.para: When the hardware status is bus-off, an application cannot communicate anymore. Consider using the parameter, which instructs the API to automatically reset the CAN controller when a bus-off state is detected.

Another way to reset bus errors like , , and others:
Performing an uninitialize / initialize cycle: This causes a hardware reset, but only when no more clients are connected to that channel.
Using the parameter : It instructs this method to explicitly perform a hardware reset regardless of whether other clients are connected to that channel.

member.param: The handle of a PCAN Channel.

returns.para: is returned if the CAN controller of the hardware represented by the given PCAN Channel is in a normal state. The typical errors in case of failure are:

: Indicates that the hardware represented by was removed or deactivated.
: Indicates that the contains an invalid value.
Indicates a bus error within the CAN controller of the hardware represented by the given PCAN Channel. An error counter reached the 'heavy' limit.
Indicates a bus error within the CAN controller of the hardware represented by the given PCAN Channel. An error counter reached the 'light' limit.
Indicates a bus error within the CAN controller of the hardware represented by the given PCAN Channel. The CAN controller is in error passive state.
Indicates a bus error within the CAN controller of the hardware represented by the given PCAN Channel. An error counter reached the 'warning' limit.
Indicates a bus error within the CAN controller of the hardware represented by the given PCAN Channel. The CAN controller is in bus-off state.

member.name: M:Peak.Can.Basic.Api.Read(Peak.Can.Basic.PcanChannel,Peak.Can.Basic.PcanMessage@)
member.summary: Reads a CAN message from the receive queue of a PCAN Channel.

remarks.note: If the timestamp of message reception is required, use the method instead.
remarks.para: The Read method returns CAN frames from the receive queue. It is important to call Read repeatedly until the receive queue becomes empty. In case there are no more messages to retrieve, the error is returned. The error is also returned if the reception of messages, configurable through the parameter, is disabled.
The receive queue can contain up to 32768 messages.

There are two possibilities for reading messages from the receive queue of a Channel:
Time-Triggered Reading: Consists in periodically calls to the Read method. Typically, an application starts a timer that checks for messages every 50 or 100 milliseconds, calling the Read method in a loop until the error or another error condition is reached.
Event-Triggered Reading: Consists in reacting to a notification sent by the PCAN driver to a registered application, when a message is received and placed in its receive queue. See Using Events to obtain more information about reading with events.

If a bus-off error occur, an application cannot use the channel to communicate anymore, until the CAN controller is reset. Consider using the parameter, which instructs the API to automatically reset the CAN controller when a bus-off state is detected.

Another way to reset bus errors like , , and others:
Performing an uninitialize / initialize cycle: This causes a hardware reset, but only when no more clients are connected to that channel.
Using the parameter : It instructs this method to explicitly perform a hardware reset regardless of whether other clients are connected to that channel.
The of a object indicates the kind of CAN frame it describes. This value should be checked every time a message has been read successfully.
If the of a contains the value , then the message is an Error Frame.
If the of a contains the value , then the message is a Status Frame.

member.param: The handle of a PCAN Channel.

param.name: msg
param.para: Contains the next available CAN frame stored in the FIFO receive queue of .
The content of msg is only valid if the returned value of this method is .

returns.para: is returned on success. The typical errors in case of failure are:

list.item: : Indicates that the contains an invalid value.
: Indicates that the cannot be used because it was not found in the list of reserved Channels of the calling application.
: Indicates that one or more of the values passed to the method are invalid.
: Indicates that there are no more messages in the receive queue of the Channel.
: Indicates that the message that has been read is not permitted due to the current settings and has been discarded.

member.exception: The underlying PCANBasic.dll library could not be found.
The execution of a PCAN-Basic related check operation ended with an unexpected result. Typically, this exception is triggered when a device driver is not installed or is not up to date.

example.para: The following example shows the use of the method using the USB interface (first PCAN-USB hardware). A Channel is initialized and used to read messages within 1 second.
In case of failure, the returned code will be translated to a text (according with the operating system language) in English, German, Italian, French or Spanish, and it will be shown to the user.

In case there are no more messages to retrieve, the error is returned. The error is also returned if the reception of messages, configurable through the parameter, is disabled.
The receive queue can contain up to 32768 messages.

There are two possibilities for reading messages from the receive queue of a Channel:
Time-Triggered Reading: Consists in periodically calls to the Read method. Typically, an application starts a timer that checks for messages every 50 or 100 milliseconds, calling the Read method in a loop until the error or another error condition is reached.
Event-Triggered Reading: Consists in reacting to a notification sent by the PCAN driver to a registered application, when a message is received and placed in its receive queue. See Using Events to obtain more information about reading with events.

If a bus-off error occur, an application cannot use the channel to communicate anymore, until the CAN controller is reset. Consider using the parameter, which instructs the API to automatically reset the CAN controller when a bus-off state is detected.

Another way to reset bus errors like , , and others:
Performing an uninitialize / initialize cycle: This causes a hardware reset, but only when no more clients are connected to that channel.
Using the parameter : It instructs this method to explicitly perform a hardware reset regardless of whether other clients are connected to that channel.
The of a object indicates the kind of CAN frame it describes. This value should be checked every time a message has been read successfully.
If the of a contains the value , then the message is an Error Frame.
If the of a contains the value , then the message is a Status Frame.

member.param: The handle of a PCAN Channel.

param.name: msg
param.para: Contains the next available CAN frame stored in the FIFO receive queue of .
The content of msg is only valid if the returned value of this method is .

param.name: timestamp
param.para: Contains the timestamp, in microseconds, of when the was received.
The content of timestamp is only valid if the returned value of this method is .

note.para: On Windows, the contains the number of microseconds elapsed since system start.
On Linux, the contains the number of microseconds elapsed since the epoch (00:00 UTC, January 1st 1970).

returns.para: is returned on success. The typical errors in case of failure are:

list.item: : Indicates that the contains an invalid value.
: Indicates that the cannot be used because it was not found in the list of reserved Channels of the calling application.
: Indicates that one or more of the values passed to the method are invalid.
: Indicates that there are no more messages in the receive queue of the Channel.
: Indicates that the message that has been read is not permitted due to the current settings and has been discarded.

In case of failure, the returned code will be translated to a text (according with the operating system language) in English, German, Italian, French or Spanish, and it will be shown to the user.

member.name: M:Peak.Can.Basic.Api.FilterMessages(Peak.Can.Basic.PcanChannel,System.UInt32,System.UInt32,Peak.Can.Basic.FilterMode)
member.summary: Configures the acceptance filter for CAN messages within a PCAN Channel.
member.remarks:
After a PCAN Channel is initialized, its filter is fully opened, causing any message received by the hardware to be placed in the receive queue of the Channel.
Based on the current state of the filter, calling this method results in the following behavior:
Status was : The filter is automatically closed and then configured with the given range of IDs passed to [, ].
Status was : The filter is set to the given range of IDs passed to [, ].
Status was : The filter is expanded with the given range of Ids [, ]. If a smaller or different range is required than a range that has been configured before, the filter has to be closed first before calling again. To do this, use the method .
The indicates which kind of ID is being used to register the new filter range. There are two possible values, Standard (11-bit identifier) or Extended (29-bit identifier). Standard frames are using the bit positions 28 to 18 of the Acceptance Mask/Code registers in the SJA1000 CAN controller. Drivers for 82C200 CAN controllers have to shift the bits down to positions 10 to 0.
Take into account that configuring the message filter causes the CAN controller to enter the reset state. This will affect other applications that communicate with the same PCAN hardware.
There is only one filter for standard and extended CAN messages. The ID from a standard message uses the most significant 11 bits (bit 18 to 28) of the 29 bits filter. I.e. the standard ID 400h is also received by indicating an extended ID 10000000h. For this reason, it is not recommended to mix standard and extended filters, since it can increase the risk of receiving unwanted messages.
Multiple calls of expand the reception filter.
It is not guaranteed that an application only receives CAN messages in the range of to . This is caused by the operating principle of the SJA1000's acceptance filter. See also Philips Data Sheet "SJA1000 Stand-alone CAN-controller.
member.param: The handle of a PCAN Channel.

The lower range value to accept and place messages in the receive queue.
The lowest value allowed is 0.The highest value allowed is 0x7FF if equals to , and 0x1FFFFFFF if equals to .

The upper range value to accept and place messages in the receive queue.
The lowest value allowed is 0. The highest value allowed is 0x7FF if equals to , and 0x1FFFFFFF if equals to .
The kind of filter to be set. This parameter restricts the range of values valid for and .

returns.para: is returned on success. The typical errors in case of failure are:

list.item: : Indicates that the contains an invalid value.
: Indicates that the cannot be used because it was not found in the list of reserved Channels of the calling application.

member.exception: The underlying PCANBasic.dll library could not be found.
The execution of a PCAN-Basic related check operation ended with an unexpected result. Typically, this exception is triggered when a device driver is not installed or is not up to date.

example.para: The following example shows the use of the method using the USB interface (first PCAN-USB hardware). A Channel is initialized and its filter is configured to get only messages with ID 2,3,4 or 5.
In case of failure, the returned code will be translated to a text (according with the operating system language) in English, German, Italian, French or Spanish, and it will be shown to the user.
